PROPOSITION.TITRE: Region in which funeral music was collected.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: I have been recording to the north of Rantepao (Rindingallo region) and, to a lesser degree, to the west and south. Between 1991 and 2001, I recorded funeral music at twenty-two funeral celebrations.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: North of Rantepao, Rindingallo Region, 2005.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The participants occasionally start singing for the deceased in the weeks before the celebration; in this case I use the term ‘mortuary vigil’. The non-Christian celebrations, which are strictly traditional and follow the aluk rule are called alukta, ‘our rule’. In general, I attended celebrations lasting from one evening to fifteen days.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: From traditional to syncretic rituals.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Between 1993 and 2001, I attended twenty-two funeral rituals either in whole or in part. Only four were performed strictly according to the traditional religion; the eleven others were Christian adaptations of the custom which excluded traditional officiants from the ritual.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Randanan, October 1993. The widower, in front of a dog sacrifice, second funeral of Indo’Serang.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: Known as aluk to dolo, these rituals mobilize a great number of sacrificed animals (puppies, dogs, hens, pigs, buffaloes). Out of twenty-two funerals attended, there were only four that were totally traditional, uninfluenced by the Christian rite. The masters of ceremony at this type of funeral are the to minaa and to mebalun officiants.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The funeral ritual consecrates a separation and a voyage.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Separation of the deceased from the living, separation of the deceased’s body and spirit, which, from the start of the rite, passes from the status of ‘life spirit’ (deata) to ‘black shade’ (bombo lotong). The latter journeys to the place of the ancestors to gain the status of ancestor (nene').
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Live funeral, Baruppu', 1993.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: In the eyes of the Toraja biological death is not recognized as true death. The deceased is deemed to be sick (to makula' ‘the one who is warm’) until the first funeral celebration, which can take place years after biological death. Meanwhile, the deceased, who rests in the house lying east-west, is fed.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The funeral ritual enables each family to affirm its rank.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Rank, inherited from the parents, is reaffirmed during the rituals through the attribution of particular words and the making and usage of diverse objects used to distinguish the classes (for example, megaliths, catafalques, and shrouds).
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Catafalque in which the deceased lies, Mengkendek, 1993.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The funeral ritual allows families to renew social ties through chains of reciprocity.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: At the funeral two groups of donors are distinguished: blood relations (pa'rapuan) and affines (to rampean). When family members bring pigs, the gifts are not considered to be debts, whereas the ‘presents ’brought by allies will be counted as debts. The debts between givers and receivers are considered to be a series of repeated pairs throughout time, not an infinite chain. (Waterson 1993: 83).
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Guests bringing gifts at a funeral celebration, Penduan Ra'ba, 2001.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The funeral ritual enables the deceased’s shade to set off downstream towards ancestorhood.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: After death the deceased’s shade (bombo) separates from the body and sets out on a long and painful journey downstream towards the river’s end, the ‘land’s tail’. It is accompanied by psychopomps –the animals –who guide it to a terrestrial realm where all the dead are, irrespective of social rank.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Mist, evoked in the songs as scenery for the journey.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Three categories of funeral rituals can be identified.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Each category of funeral depends on social rank, which determines the number of buffaloes, nights and the quantity of music. The higher the status, the more splendid and ostentatious the funeral. The categories vary from region to region.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Three categories of funeral rites, according to Ne’ Lumbaa, p. c., 2001.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: 1) Funeral with no buffalo sacrifice.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The dead celebrated without buffalo are foetuses, stillborn babies, children who die before teething (buried in a tree trunk for a grave) and the poor and descendents of slaves. If no buffalo is killed, the deceased’s spirit cannot be transformed into divinity. The sacrifices consist of an egg, a hen, or a pig. No building is built; no song, poem, or invocation is pronounced.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Child’s funeral at Baruppu', 1993.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The most sophisticated funeral ritual takes place in two stages at two places, separated by an interval varying from one month to several years.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The first funeral marks the transformation of the ‘invalid’ –long dead biologically –into a true deceased. It signifies the symbolic death of the body, which only then is turned head downstream and then hung from the ceiling. The second funeral allows the deceased’s shade –represented by an effigy –set off to appear at the home of the dead downstream, accompanied by the riches sacrificed for him during the rituals.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Sequences of the first funeral ceremony (ma'puli).
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The name of the first funeral celebration is ‘finding death at the same moment’ (ma'puli). The action unrolls in three places: 1) the deceased’s house 2) the courtyard –where the buffaloes are slaughtered and the meat shared out, the site for speeches, dancing and singing 3) and lastly, the megalithic field where buffaloes are also slaughtered and divided, and where the ceremonial trident mast is planted. The celebration lasts five to seven nights.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: Inside the house, the funeral officiant (to mebalun) raises the deceased’s basket before constructing an evacuation system: a bamboo pipe joining the body to the ground through the floor of the house. The aim is to collect symbolically all the corpse’s liquids (ma'pasusu). PROPOSITION.TITRE: The intermediary period constitutes a pause between the two funeral celebrations.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: At the end of the first funeral celebration, the clothes of the deceased’s kin are dyed black (ossoran badong, line 784). During the intermediary period between the two celebrations –which can last from a few days to several years –, music is not allowed. The children go about bargaining for the largest number of buffaloes, at the best price for the sake of the final celebration (line 808). The corpse stays hanging from the ceiling of the house (lines 828, 829).

PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The second celebration can last from seven to nine nights. Named ‘descending [in procession to the ceremonial field]’ (ma'pasonglo, ma'palao), it consists of a succession of moves of the body which will be taken down from the ceiling to the floor, then to the ground of the courtyard, then lifted to the rice granary, then again taken in procession to the ceremonial field, put on a tower and, after the sacrifices, carried to its grave. PROPOSITION.TITRE: The ma’nene’ rite allows the deceased’s spirit to attain ancestorhood.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The choice of the funeral poem sung depends on the deceased’s social rank and the rite performed.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The words of the badong songs are of two types. Whereas the aristocrats have the right to a sung hagiographic recitation deifying them, the less noble have only the right to discontinuous stanzas. The two types are differentiated only by the character of the lyrics. The melodies themselves are no different from one social class to another.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: In order to transform the deceased’s spirit into an ancestor the collectivity elevates him to a superior rank by praising his exemplary nature so that the gods welcome him among them. The ossoran badong (‘narrative of the badong’) is a long hagiographic poem of which only certain parts are sung. It is the history of the life of a deceased who, through the utterance of a eulogistic lamentation, will be raised to the rank of ancestor, an elevation analogous to beatification in the Christian world.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The metrical structure of the badong is based on the octosyllable.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: In the badong, the lines are most often grouped in couplets of either two octosyllables (8-8) or an octosyllable and a heptasyllable (8-7), but they can also be grouped by three (8-8-8), by four (8-8-8-8) or five (8-8-7-8-8), the third line then being a heptasyllable.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: There are two categories of badong, depending on the timing of the ritual: badong in unison and antiphonal badong.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: When marking the corpse’s movements and welcoming the guests, the song is in unison, without alternation of soloists. When not used to mark the body’s movements, the song is more often antiphonal in response, with two or four soloist groups (badong sibali-bali), with alternating solos.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The song is in unison when the body is moved, to indicate true moments of contact and an announcement of a separation between the living and the deceased. The circle is then open to all who wish –even those who do not know how to sing: they just dance in silence.

ANTECEDENT.TITRE: The line is pronounced by two groups.
ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: This is the oldest type of division. It is called badong sipenduanri ‘by two’, or duang tetukri ‘by two corners’, as the line is pronounced by two groups only, supported by the chorus. The line is pronounced immediately after these two groups. The clausula is then intoned, a fixed formula of praise, which occupies the remainder of the song and which is carried by groups 3 and 4 and the chorus. In this model the quarters take no part in uttering the line. The groups are not in a relationship of equal status. Two sub-models exist (1 and 2): either the chorus intervenes between two groups, or it intervenes between each group.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Model of a line divided in two.

ANTECEDENT.TITRE: The line is pronounced by four groups.
ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The badong sipenda'pa (‘badong in four’) is also called patang tetuk (‘in four corners’). The line is pronounced by the four ‘corners’ in succession. Each soloist group makes its contribution. Group 1 often pronounces three syllables, groups 2 and 3 two syllables, and group 4 one. After the first round when the line has been pronounced, the singers do another, with a different line that is a clausula in the form of praise: the first says ‘alas’ (oyode), the second ‘what a pity’ (kallae), the third ‘golden chignon’ (lokkon bulayan) or ‘golden horns’ (tanduk bulayan) for a man, and the fourth ‘gold leaf’ (don bulayan), then oh mother or oh father (o indo’/o ambe). In this model, the relationships of the voices are equal in status.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: Anadiplosis, a typical badong procedure, is used to generate the singing: each group succeeds the one before by repeating its last vowel or syllable.

PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Despite the religious importance of the words as part of the ‘ritual rule’ (aluk), the words as sung are unrecognizable, owing to the antiphonal singing, melismatic style, vowel deformation, and playing with the harmonic spectra.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: Every syllable is sung on more than about eight notes, which prevents the line from being easily reconstituted. Although the words produce ritual efficacy, as soon as they are sung they are taken apart phoneme by phoneme. The words are atomised and dismembered and the regularity of the octosyllables disappears.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: All the vowels are reduced to the middle aperture vowels [o] and [e] (sounding é). The transformation of the vowels ([a], [i], [u]) into the vowels ([e]and [o] ) corresponds to a reduction in aperture. Each time the movement is from rounded to non-rounded, from wide or narrow aperture to middle: so, the mouth is always almost closed. In the vocalic triangle, the vowels [e] and [o] are in a relationship of symmetric opposition. Thus, the aperture does not change but the point of articulation does –it passes from front to back.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The passage of the vowels [o] to [e] is termed ‘turnaround’ (basse). It is radical and not diffused. It is done abruptly: on the vowel [o], the spectrum is stretched from H1 to H4 only, whereas on the [e] the spectrum is widened considerably beyond 4 kHz giving rise to two or three formant zones as well as strong energy on H2 and H7. While the formants of [o] are close together those of [e] wide apart. This alternation of opposed spectra –one broad and the other narrow –is the base of the aesthetic of the badong.

PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Though the badong is meant to be sung in unison, it is rarely strict: the leaders deliberately enrich the unison along the extremely reduced melodic line. So with a rich harmonic density the badong can be sung in unison, in heterophony, or sometimes in parallel movements.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The individual ornamentation is done by a soloist who ‘sings between the voices’ a second above or below the chorus (mangindo’i). He embroiders, ‘he directs by leaving the common road, he branches off to make the sound more pleasant’. This form of counterpoint in second is called ma'garente ‘quivering, vibrating, pleasant to hear’ or ma’kirrokan ‘rubbing or grating sound’. This procedure allows several melodies to be heard.

ANTECEDENT.TITRE: Collective ornamentation of the melodic line.
ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The singers may embroider together in unison. The chorus memorizes the melody with its ornaments. Embellishments of a melodic nature are detectable through small groups of joined tones bunching together with a downward or upward movement on the recitation tone. The variety of ornamental cells contrasts with the bare horizontality of the reciting tone. Added to the reciting tone, these groups of ornaments tend to become the melody itself.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: To an outsider’s ear, the choruses have the effect of unified humming masses. The resonance is certainly connected to the acoustics of the space, but also to the harmonic structure. Thick, bubbling, and intensely close, the badong’s musical flesh results from a polyphony of harmonics flowing from the unison. In spectrogram 2, the 30 singers share the line te allona ri batara between the four soloist groups and the chorus. The spectrogram shows the harmonic density of the chorus over the first 20 harmonics. On the vowel [e], the energy is particularly reinforced around 2000 Hz on h7 and h8. This reinforcement of the intensity when the chorus comes in after the solos 3 and 4 results in the presence of darker vertical bands.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The melodico-rhythmic formulas are made up of four or five melodic cells.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Each badong song presents a fairly short melodic phrase, composed like woven material by the addition of four or five four beat melodic cells developing in a restricted ambitus, on two fundamental degrees at a distance of one or two tones.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: It is surprising to realize that nearly all the badong are in four beats. The note values are simple, the smallest unit being no larger than a semiquaver (sixteenth note). Most often, the first strong beat is a crotchet (quarter note),and the last weak beat in the bar is divided in two, as is shown by this five bar melodico-rhythmic matrix.

The melodic cells are often repeated, as the shading in the first two boxes shows. The melodico-rhythmic phrases are composed like a tapestry or draughts board through the addition of four-beat melodic segments.

The basic melodic skeleton, restricted, rests on two essential degrees one tone apart. These degrees correspond to the recitation (figure 6) and termination functions (figure 5). The badong’s scale can be enriched according to different configurations. It then presents four modalities.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The dynamism results first of all from the impulses given physically by the dancers’ arms and legs on the first and third beats, intensified by slight retardations. It also arises from attacking the pitches a second below.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The retteng is distinguished by a lean vocal style.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The end of the musical phrase is marked by an abrupt vocal emaciation, perceived as a harmonic impoverishment. At first reinforced in the first twenty harmonics, the spectrum is suddenly reduced to the first harmonic only. The change of phonatory mechanism, placed in the middle and end of the phrase, is one of the specific features of retteng chanting, reserved for experienced soloists able to master this type of vibratory alternation.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: From funeral chant in solo retteng to mate (Barto, from Buntao'). The extract analyzed shows that the elision of the last syllable is marked by an abrupt vocal emaciation, marked by a sudden harmonic impoverishment.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The retteng’s literary content aims either to praise the deceased or resolve conflicts through an improvised dialogue (siretteng).
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The retteng’s content is more aggressive and satirical than the badong. It is either a personal homage to the deceased, the expression of chagrin at his death (retteng malolo lako to mate), or a socio-political questioning through a satire on the protagonists present, leading to a heated debate or even real fighting (Sandarupa 2004: 231).

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The poem is composed by each singer who chooses conventional rhetorical figures. The singer speaks in the first person singular, unlike the badong where the narrator speaks in the first person plural. The retteng singer can take liberties with the contents of what he says. Some examples of rettengs are available in Veen 1966, Koubi 1982, Sandarupa 2004.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The retteng sindun ‘retteng generating an opposite view’ takes the form of a debate between several singers. A symbolic violence is unleashed in their verbal jousting, which can lead to a real combat (Sandarupa 2004: 231). In the most stratified region (tallu lembangna), these confrontations through retteng are still frequent –see the analysis in S. Sandarupa’s thesis.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The literary contents of the dondi’ reveal a collective emotional lyricism.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The dondi’ expresses at once the singers’ worries and sorrow, their joy at being together, and their sentiments, mixed with aphorisms and symbolic images. The considerations are expressed by the chorus in the first person plural who tells of his sadness and the journey of the deceased, addresses the spirit of the deceased or the singer friend, pronounces maxims, and tells of affectionate thoughts.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Dondi’ songs have a psalmodic form.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Dondi’ songs are rooted in a collective utterance of the words. This utterance is based on a melody organized in three periods: ascent to a reciting tone, recitation on a single tone, then back down to a terminal pitch, the whole interrupted by median inflections (or mediatio).

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Intonation, recitation, termination in the dondi’.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The scale is based on a succession of four pitches, each having a function of unequal importance in the recitative structure: intonation (or final) tone, terminal tone, reciting tone, and sometimes ornamental note a semitone or tone above. The scale offers two modalities depending on the ornamental note’s pitch. These two scales can be used alternatively to engender intervals of minor second, major second, minor third and fourth. The ambitus of the dondi’ is narrow.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: The first form of the scale is anhemitonic and founded on three principal pitches with specific functions: a tone for intonation, an ornamented reciting tone and a terminal tone.

The second form of scale used is hemitonic; it is determined by four pitches: intonation tone, reciting tone, ornamental tone (a semitone above the reciting tone), and terminal tone. Celebrated for its expressive power, this scale is much used in the Pangngala’ region.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The bare linear profile is due to the sustained insistence on the recitation tone which finishes abruptly with an acceleration on a paroxytone (stress on the penultimate syllable) and elision of the last syllable of the line.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Dondi’ line end.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The ‘median inflection’ –or mediatio - marks the passage of the recitation tone to the terminal tone and at the same time to the intonation tone. It underlines the end of the semantic units, indicates a syntactic pause by vocalizing the last syllable of the semantic unit (of the line or hemistich), and thus segments the line by giving a limit to the unit of metric structure. In this way the structure of the line is reinforced by an exact coincidence between musical articulations and metric pauses, stresses of grammatical units, hemistiches, and line ends, as is illustrated by the example opposite.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Syllabic dondi’ and mediatio. The song descends to the final tone by means of the median inflection (in the box), in the middle of the first line and at the end of the second line. The place of the musical median inflection respects the metric pause of the poetic line.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: From the syllabic to the melismatic in the dondi’ funeral repertoire.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Depending on the treatment of the syllables, this repertoire can be from a simple, almost chanted song to one that is ornate and vocalized. The melody plays the role of an elastic mould to welcome the lines. Certain moulds, small and tight, arrange the words neatly; others, more flexible, let them stretch out as they like.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: In the syllabic dondi’, the beats are distributed over a melodico-rhythmic cycle, defined by the regular repetition of accents. This cycle can be based on the recurrence of a single four-beat rhythmic figure (type of matrix), repeated a fixed number of times. It can also be longer, founded on the succession of four- or five- beat rhythmic segments. Not all the lines are adapted to all the melodies. Tradition has fixed certain lines on certain melodies.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Dondi’ performed according to a four-beat matrix.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: In the syllabic dondi’, poetic and musical meters do not contradict each other. The eight-beat musical phrase corresponds to the eight-syllable verse. The music still depends strictly on the lyrics.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Metrical and musical pauses correspond.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: In the melismatic dondi’, we can see different ways to evacuate the word’s intelligibility (letter B): verbal asphyxia by adding a monosyllable (le, o, io), whole or partial repetition of a word previously pronounced, repetition by anticipation (the word of the following verse is anticipated to announce it), ornamental profusion.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Melismas, accumulation, and distortion in the dondi’.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: In the melismatic dondi’, whether transformed, altered or elided, the open vowels are replaced by more closed vowels: the [a] becomes open or closed [e], the [u] – [o] (letter C: kayu is sung keyu and rante becomes rente). The deformation furthers the musical aesthetic because it favors the fusion of timbres.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Melismas, accumulation, and distortion in the dondi’.

ANTECEDENT.TITRE: Non-coincidence between metrical series and musical accents.
ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: In the melismatic dondi’, the musical accents that articulate the octo- or heptasyllabic metrical series are no longer always the same as those of spoken language: the music no longer systematically reflects the metrical structure of the poetry. And this is because the mediatio has lost its function: the passage to the fundamental no longer corresponds to a metrical pause. It no longer appears to mark the structure of the verse; it appears at the beginning, middle or at the end of a word, on a consonant or a vowel in total melisma; sometimes, it even disappears.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: The mediatio in the melismatic dondi’ no longer indicates a poetic segment. The melodic descent no longer serves to emphasize the metrical pause. NB: the backings a fifth above (sung by the women) and an octave below (sung by a single man) have not been noted here.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The emancipation of the voice can be felt still more in the ‘un-measuring’ of the time, in the slowness of the tempo. The melismatic dondi’ rests on an aesthetic of dilution (temporal dilution, dilution of vowels). Stretched out by vocalisms, no longer corresponding to the poetic meter, the meter is abused. The pulse is no longer isochronous. Time flows in a space organized by irregular accents and an underlying pulse. Here, the idea of strong beat and weak beat disappears. The quality of the singing in the dondi’ of melismatic type arises mainly from this less perceptible flow of time.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Repertoires similar to the dondi’ in other regions.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Each region has developed particular sitting choruses for its dead. The dondi’ is sung in the north and the west (Rindingallo and Saluputti). Nonetheless, sengo and unnosong, sung in other regions, have similar features: they are also performed seated, in chorus, for funerals. The difference lies in the melodies used and the stock of lines. The pace of the sengo is more static than the dondi’’s in the melodies and scales used. The pace of the unnosong is different: it is only sung responsorially, and only by men.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: In the region of Gandang Batu, the performance of the sengo has features in common with the dondi’: performed seated, indoors, and in chorus, it entertains the participants by evoking death and passing away. The difference is in the melodies used and the stock of lines. The sengo has a more static pace than the dondi’ owing to its melodic lines and scales. On the textual level it resemble the lamentation marakka. Moreover, the quatrains have titles –some with probable authors.

When they brought the coffee the guests gave money (t) to the women who sang on several themes –paying homage, praising the guests’ grandeur, and describing their dishes with litotes.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The female dance joge’ is evidence of borrowing from Bugis culture.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Of the musical aesthetic, the choreography, and the words –none are properly Toraja. The dance joge’ comes from the Bugis dance pa' joge’, imported into Toraja country through the ancient ties existing between the Toraja sovereigns and those of the kingdom of Luwu', on the eastern coast (Nooy-Palm 1979: 91). The Bugis joge’, much appreciated by the 31st Raja of Boné, was sung by a troupe of dancing-girls holding fans and wearing sarongs, accompanied by the sound of two-headed drums, singing in unison in high tessitura (Holt 1939: 98-103). This dance was prohibited during the twentieth century owing to its alluring sexuality, considered contrary to public morality. The games between a female dancer and a (male) member of the audience, initiated during the dance, led the dancers into amorous adventures. The joge’ was eventually replaced with transvestites (the pa' joge’angkong) because too many dancers became pregnant.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Dance joge’, funeral at To' Malolo, Sa'dan, 1993.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: Out of ten songs collected, four are in Toraja, three in Bugis, one in Makassar, one song mixes Bugis and Makassar, and one song Toraja and Bugis. The singers do not understand what they are singing nor even know what language it might be in. Being fragmentary, the Bugis-Makassar words are difficult to translate. The Toraja words function according to the usual meter in octosyllabic couplets, using the same thematic as the dondi’ repertoires, badong and marakka –the expression of sadness and the depiction of the journey of the deceased. The Bugis-Makassar words do not function in pairs. The words glorify the nobility but their meaning is drowned in incoherence, as for example in this song pa'denda.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The dance joge’ is widespread in Indonesia. The term comes from the word joged designating a dance that is part of the Malay cultural heritage. It is still commonly employed by various languages and in all the islands of Indonesia, but refers to different realities in every case. In Indonesian, joged nowadays means ‘dance to variety music’. See Yampolsky 1996, Music of Indonesia vol. 11. For joge’ in Sulawesi, see Kaudern 1929: 474-477; Holt 1939: 89-93, Kennedy 1953: 103, 104. Bugis joge’ and jaga have been filmed by Rolf de Maré (1938). In the film (Reel 102 preserved at Stockholm), two types of joge’ are presented: the joge’ filmed at Sengkang performed by two transvestites (wandu), with chignon and fan, and the joge’ filmed at Pampanua (south of Sengkang) performed by twelve girls to the sound of drums.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Joge’ dancer in Bugis country, in Holt 1939. In the ancient Bugis-Makassar kingdoms, each sovereign retained a troupe of young professional dancing girls. If these dancers performed in public, they were paid and took the name of pa'joge’. Restricted court dances also existed, danced exclusively by princes and princesses such as the Bugis ma' jaga or the Makassar pakarena. Unlike the joge’ dancers the jaga dancing girls belonged to the sovereign and were not hired out (Kennedy 1953: 103, Matthes 1975: 126).

Female joge’ dancers in Bugis country, in Holt 1939. According to R. Kennedy, the joge’ dancers are professional, semi-prostitutes, ‘slaves’ belonging to nobles who own the troupes. They can be sold, either for a night or for life; they worked in the kitchen as well. R. Kennedy (1953: 103) said: ‘The dancing of the padjoge is not festive, and there is little gaiety. The men who are dancing are as deadpan as the women and all are deadly serious’. The dancing girls have the facial expression of slaves, self-contained, inexpressive ‘sinister, never raising their eyes. A dance with a joge’, or a song sung by her upon request, would last fifteen minutes and cost two dollars. Once a man who paid complained because the padjoge dancer did not lower herself enough in front of him.
From Raymond Kennedy’s notes, 1953, Field Notes on Indonesia South Celebes, 1949–1950: 141.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: Unlike the Toraja melodies based on hemitonic tetraphonic scales, the melodies of the joge’ are often based on an anhemitonic pentatonic scale. Moreover, the length of the musical phrase contrasts with the repeated short phrases of Toraja songs. Lastly, in the joge’ with borrowed melodies, the melodic curve is more varied and rhythmic –with an abundance of more square motifs, but still melismatic all the same.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The marakka is a female lamentation accompanied by the flute.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: A local tradition, peculiar to the region of Buntao’ and rarely performed, the marakka has practically disappeared. Today it is performed by one to four people: one or two singers and one or two flautists (there used to be a violin geso'-geso' as well). The musicians play at the guests’ arrival and formerly could guide the procession accompanying the deceased from the house to the ceremonial field.

PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The guests’ arrival is in itself a great funeral scene which can last for several hours. Every procession, first male then female, that enters the courtyard area is introduced by a marakka singer and flautist who lead them to where they are given areca nut.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The words of the marakka are an elegy, lamentation, and complaint.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The words, often composed by named authors, sometimes still alive, refer to four protagonists: the family, guests (not mentioned in the repertoires previously discussed), the deceased, and singers. Several thematic groups may be distinguished: lamentation, separation, journey, aphorisms on human destiny, entertainment, and homage to the guests.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The versification of the marakka is different from that of the dondi’ and badong repertoires. The lines are grouped in quatrains (formed of an octosyllable, a heptasyllable, a pentasyllable or octosyllable and then a heptasyllable: 8-7-5-7 or 8-7-8-7) or in five-line stanzas.

PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: In the marakka song and the londe recited couplets, the lines are grouped in quatrains. The particularity of these quatrains is that the third line only has five syllables: 8-7-5-7. This form may be sung in dondi’, never in badong.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: A melodic line close to tears.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The songs’ static nature is rooted in the nearly absolute linearity of the melody with its imperceptible pulse. The melody offers few supports and slides smoothly with ornate short values from high to low towards the ultimate chromaticism - E natural –like a plaintive sigh, in the heart of the moaning, where the word appears to add to the expression.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Pa’Indo’Tobong, recorded at Buntao’, 1993.

ANTECEDENT.TITRE: Fusion of voice and flute timbres.
ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The flutes suling and the female voices are strictly in unison. The female voices –the women are between 35 and 60 years old –try to fuse with the flute’s timbre. The flute players play with a wide vibrato; they make use of the circular breathing technique.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Pa' So Bilang, recorded at Buntao’ in 1993.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The voices seem tense, but the tessitura is not especially high (520Hz, around C 3). One of the characteristics of the voices of the marakka is the tension and color of the voices.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: From a novel by Harry Wilcox, Six Moons in Celebes, 1949: 58.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The inordinate stretching of the syllables over several pitches (melismas), and scrambling through extreme ornamentation, help make the song totally incomprehensible.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Piece of marakka, Buntao’, 1993.

ANTECEDENT.TITRE: Static nature of the melodic line pulse.
ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The pulse is slow and weak, barely noticeable. In the absence of a real melodic structure it escapes, disguises itself, and does not let itself be grasped. It is present all the same. The songs’ static nature is due to the almost perfect linearity of the melody and the weak affirmation of the pulse.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Song Pa' Indo’Tobong.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The music of marakka, more than the round-dance badong, whets grieving among the Toraja. The timbres are taut, and the melody falls back into desolation with a poignant unison of flutes of voices. The impression of giddiness, exhilaration, and virtuosity, the transports of the fiercely stretched female voice are what characterizes the marakka and what alarms western listeners, who little appreciate the static melodies, the languor of the suspended long stretched-out notes interrupted by short ornate passages, described in vivid images by a British traveller.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: From Harry Wilcox, Six moons in Sulawesi (1949) 1989: 57.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The pentatonic scale peculiar to the marakka.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The peculiarity of the marakka is its pentatonic scale of slendro type (with nearly equal intervals) but broadened towards the hexatonic by using a lower semitone as support. This descending melodic chromaticism musically suggests complaint and lamentation.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: ‘Pa'Sangkombong’, recorded at Buntao’ in 1993. The complete scale is played by the flute.
A well-known piece from the marakka repertoire: Pa'Bila Bulo.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The Toraja marakka song borrows melodies from neighbors in the plains.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: A few exogenous tunes, about 10% of the repertoire, probably borrowed from the Bugis repertoire, have been inserted in the marakka. Unlike the static and melismatic type, the borrowed tunes are more rhythmic and isochronous, are well-built melodically, and make use of an anhemitonic scale. No melismas or rhythmic indecision here. The form of the marakka –solo singing and flute –is also found in Makassar language in Kajang country.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Pa'Callele, marakka song, at Buntao’ in 1993.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The anhemitonic pentatonic scale of slendro type gives an immediately different color.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Pa'Danduru Dalle, Buntao’, 1993. The scale and the words here are distinguished from most other marakka singing.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: In the commune of Tana Toa (Kec. Kajang, Kab. Bulukumba), in South Sulawesi, three hundred kilometers from the Toraja mountains, there is a type of women’s singing accompanied by the five-holed flute (basing), with a coloration strangely reminiscent of the marakka repertoire. Both have an identical formation and a melodic profile with features in common.
